Because Devils Lake is [[endorheic]], the lake tends to be much higher in [[salinity]] than are lakes with outlets to river systems. This is similar to the [[Great Salt Lake]] in [[Utah]].<ref name="Rosenberg">Rosenberg, Sheryl A. 2000. "A Canadian Perspective on the Devils Lake Outlet: Towards an Environmental Assessment Model for the Management of Transboundary Disputes." +
Because Devils Lake is [[endorheic]], the lake tends to be much higher in [[salinity]] than are lakes with outlets to river systems. This is similar to the [[Great Salt Lake]] in [[Utah]].<ref name="Rosenberg">Rosenberg, Sheryl A. 2000. "A Canadian Perspective on the Devils Lake Outlet: Towards an Environmental Assessment Model for the Management of Transboundary Disputes." ''North Dakota Law Review'' 76: 817-59.</ref> Lower water levels increase salinity threatening fish and wildlife.<ref name="Rosenberg" /> Salinity levels in the lake have been one prominent aspect of the debate over diversion of lake water into the [[Sheyenne River]], with questions of the potential environmental impact of the diverted water on downstream rivers, lakes, and communities.<ref name="Hollis" />
